stream_context.summary: Kaze integrates major art/level updates from Biobak for the Zoo course (including Aquarium, Prison, and minigame areas), fixes Fast64/material issues, resolves interaction and crash bugs introduced by recent engine/behavior changes, and outlines upcoming structured playtesting plus technical groundwork for multiplayer. Zeina contributes textures and an in-progress dance animation enabled by a new frame-streaming animation system.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete pipeline/process changes (monthly single-course playtests), a key technical shift (streaming animation frames for longer animations), several engine/behavior bug fixes affecting NPC interaction and stability, and strong statements about design philosophy (embracing risk vs modern frictionless design).

findings.summary: Kaze spent the week preparing infrastructure for multiplayer: new code, minor performance improvements, stability work, and added engine functionality, with the stated goal of implementing multiplayer soon.

He plans to reinstate “monthly course testing”: distributing a ROM with a single course to one tester at a time to evaluate gameplay quality and align results with design intent; Course 1 is the first candidate because it’s currently the only course considered “ready.”
The project now has smoother scene/area transitions; Kaze highlights an updated transition that slides in rather than popping instantly.

Biobak delivered a substantial visual/geo rework of the Zoo course (bricks, benches, bushes, aquarium signage/jokes, prison layout, Wario office props, etc.), while Kaze reviews changes in-engine, flags issues, and notes he’ll need to remake collision maps to match the updated geometry.
Kaze identifies a Fast64 viewport/render discrepancy (textures/UV appearance) and confirms the level looks correct in-game, treating it as a Fast64 preview bug rather than a game asset problem.

He repeatedly runs into material/combiners pitfalls: Fast64 “SM64 presets” don’t always behave in RTYI due to engine changes; he discourages using shade/environment color alpha in certain materials and suggests maintaining a standard solid-material last combiner column (0,0,0,1) for reliability.

Several Zoo/Aquarium readability issues are identified for iteration: aquarium glass is nearly invisible (needs stronger reflective/tinted look), water visibility/color consistency needs adjustment, and Unagi can be used to skip aquarium progression unless a wall is raised.

A gameplay-critical regression prevented Mario from talking to NPCs/objects; Kaze traces it to behavior-script interaction fields being reset (interaction subtype/status set to 0) and quickly patches it, framing it as an acceptable cost of moving fast and fixing targeted breakages.
findings.quote: Checking the entire game would have taken longer than just fixing it.

findings.summary: A separate crash investigation reveals object field corruption tied to a reused/overlapping object-field offset (notably around 0x3D–0x3E), causing an invalid behavior command pointer; Kaze resolves it by restoring/keeping a safe value (0x40) and confirms the issue source.

Kaze describes a new animation approach: streaming individual animation frames into memory instead of loading full animations at once, allowing much longer character animations as long as cartridge space permits.

Zeina creates/supplies a new “butt print” decal texture and is building a dance animation for “Mari,” aided by Yoshi Milkman’s and Zeina’s IK rig; Kaze explicitly credits the rig as enabling faster/better animation work.
findings.quote: Yoshi Milkman and Zeina’s IK rig are godsend. And they deserve a medal for that.

findings.summary: Kaze articulates a deliberate design stance against overly frictionless modern game design: he wants RTYI to take risks, allow struggle, and accept that players may get briefly stuck, rather than smoothing every edge to avoid frustration.
findings.quote: I take a lot more risk in my game than what you would see in a Nintendo game.

findings.summary: Kaze frames harsh external feedback as valuable if it’s specific and diagnostic, preferring candid criticism over empty positivity for improving level quality.
findings.quote: If they can point out why it’s shit, that’s the most useful thing that you can get.

findings.summary: Kaze states that the engine and the entire hack are intended to be completely open source.
findings.quote: The engine will be completely open source. The entire hack here will be open source.

findings.summary: RTYI’s scope is reiterated: planned as ~15 main courses (with additional sub/secondary content implied, “like 30”), and includes optional “achievement statue” rewards for a plane minigame (time record, no-damage run, final-boss completion) that persist and do not affect progression.

biobak.summary: Provided a wide-ranging visual and layout pass on the Zoo course, including darker corner shading inspired by “Mario Stadium,” updated benches, gates, bushes, signs/jokes, aquarium layout tweaks (vents as entry dressing), prison atmosphere upgrades, and Wario office prop references.

Delivered multiple object updates (blooper, chain chomp, chain chomp gate/door, tire swing, Dory, cheep-cheep variants, boat/table assets) that required Kaze to reconcile materials, culling settings, bone/armature quirks, and Fast64/export regressions.
Introduced/expanded comedic environmental storytelling via signage and set dressing (e.g., “Please feed the animals,” burger stand, treasure-room theming for Wario’s hoard, garlic plate in office).

zeina.summary: Created and sent an updated symmetrical “butt print” decal texture for the Zoo cement/ground detail.

Is producing a “Mari” dance animation and benefits from an IK rig workflow; Kaze indicates the new frame-streaming animation technique will allow Zeina to extend animations significantly beyond prior memory constraints.
Appears on stream, chats with Kaze, and briefly takes over to entertain viewers with drawings while Kaze steps away, reflecting an integrated home/work dynamic during development.

findings.summary: Contributed updates to zip lines to look more coherent in the level; also provided troubleshooting context on an animation-format mismatch affecting a room Kaze had last sent.
Credited (by Kaze) for an IK rig setup that significantly improves/accelerates character animation work.
Referenced as someone who may be allowed to disclose details about a separate, NDA-bound project; implies Kaze is under contractual constraints for other work while developing RTYI.
Appears in chat briefly; no concrete dev contribution discussed in this stream.

key_stories.title: Reinstating monthly single-course playtesting
key_stories.summary: Kaze proposes a structured QA cadence: once per month, one person will playtest a single course via a dedicated ROM build. He wants feedback on gameplay feel and whether the course matches intended design, starting with Course 1 as the only course currently considered ready.
key_stories.challenge: Ensuring course gameplay holds up (difficulty, clarity, feel) before the project advances further, without relying on ad-hoc feedback or testing unfinished art passes.
key_stories.process: Plan to package one-level ROMs and recruit a single tester per course; prioritize courses already reworked by Biobak to avoid testing placeholder iterations.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete testing process is announced; Kaze notes he still needs to choose a Course 1 tester and will iterate course-by-course.

key_stories.title: NPC interaction breakage traced to behavior-script field resets
key_stories.summary: While reviewing Zoo updates, Kaze discovers he can’t talk to penguins or other interactables. He identifies that recent changes cause the interaction subtype/status to be set to 0 via behavior-script handling and patches it quickly.
key_stories.challenge: A regression blocked mission progression/entry to areas (interaction-dependent gates/dialogue), threatening basic playability.
key_stories.process: Kaze bisects recent changes mentally, inspects the behavior-script logic, and updates the relevant interaction field assignment to stop it from being reset improperly.
key_stories.outcome: Interaction functionality is restored; Kaze uses it to justify his rapid iteration style (fix targeted breakages vs full-playthrough testing every change).
key_stories.key_quote: Well, am I supposed to just play the entire game every time I make any change? That is completely unreasonable.

key_stories.title: Stability/crash bug from object-field overlap corrupting behavior pointers
key_stories.summary: Kaze hits a crash and investigates at the assembly/symbol level, discovering object state values are being written into a field that later acts like a behavior command pointer. The incorrect value causes the behavior command processor to read nonsense and crash.
key_stories.challenge: A low-level crash with unclear cause, likely RAM corruption/struct offset misuse after engine refactors.
key_stories.process: Debugging via addresses/symbols, checking inlining/compiled output, and tracking suspicious object-field offsets; he concludes that a reused offset (around 0x3D–0x3E) is implicated and fixes by restoring/keeping a safe configuration (0x40).
key_stories.outcome: Crash cause is identified and mitigated; Kaze regains stability to continue integrating Zoo assets and behaviors.

key_stories.title: Animation pipeline shift: streaming individual frames
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains a new animation playback technique that streams individual frames into memory instead of loading whole animations, which reduces RAM pressure and enables longer animations if ROM space allows. This directly supports Zeina’s work on a “Mari” dance animation.
key_stories.challenge: N64-era memory constraints limiting animation length/complexity and making expressive character animation harder.
key_stories.process: Implement a frame-streaming technique, then coordinate with Zeina’s animation work (and IK rig workflow) to take advantage of longer sequences.
key_stories.outcome: Animations can be extended significantly; Kaze tells Zeina she can make the dance “as long as you want” within cart space limits.
key_stories.key_quote: You can make it as long as you want. Because… we’re loading individual frames of the animation into memory.

key_stories.title: Integrating Biobak’s Zoo rework while reconciling Fast64/material constraints
key_stories.summary: Kaze imports and tests Biobak’s updated Zoo/Aquarium/Prison geometry and objects, repeatedly encountering mismatches between Fast64 preview, RTYI’s modified engine, and material/combiner settings (fog, shade/environment alpha, culling defaults).
key_stories.challenge: Art upgrades improve the course’s look but introduce technical cleanup: UV fixes, culling toggles, transparency issues, near-invisible aquarium glass, and exporter/tooling regressions.
key_stories.process: Validate in-game vs Fast64 preview, correct UV mapping, adjust materials and combiner settings, disable culling broadly, and create a growing to-do list for collisions and readability improvements.
key_stories.outcome: Most objects are imported and functioning; remaining work centers on collision map remakes and a shortlist of material/readability fixes.

open_questions.context: Kaze says he prepared code/functionality for multiplayer and wants it implemented before releasing the Worms Fortress HD demo; he insists it should be in one ROM rather than a separate multiplayer ROM.
questions: What exact multiplayer model is planned (split-screen, online via emulator netplay assumptions, or local controller-based)?
What engine systems had to change first (camera, object ownership, physics, input, memory)?
Why does a separate ROM feel like “cheating” to him, and what are the technical blockers to one-ROM multiplayer?
What does “prepared a lot of stuff we need” include specifically (data structures, netcode assumptions, determinism, etc.)?

open_questions.context: Kaze will select one tester per month to play a single-course ROM build, starting with Course 1, and will prioritize courses after Biobak’s reworks.
questions: How will testers be selected (skill level, familiarity with SM64, speedrunners vs casual)?
What feedback format does Kaze want (written notes, recorded playthrough, interview, telemetry)?
What constitutes ‘course is ready’ and how does Biobak’s art pass factor into gameplay readiness?
How will findings be tracked and turned into actionable changes month-to-month?

open_questions.context: Kaze claims animations can be arbitrarily long by streaming frames into RAM as needed, bounded by cartridge space; this unlocks longer dances and more expressive characters.
questions: How does the frame-streaming system work technically (ROM layout, DMA scheduling, cache strategy)?
What are the performance costs/tradeoffs vs classic animation tables?
How are multiple animations handled per actor (separate sequences, blending, interruption)?
What new creative plans did this enable (cutscenes, boss animations, NPC idles)?

open_questions.topic: RTYI engine divergence from SM64 and its impact on tools
open_questions.context: Kaze notes Fast64’s SM64 presets don’t reliably work in RTYI due to engine changes (lighting/shading model, combiners, fog behavior), causing artists’ materials to break visually.
questions: What engine changes most commonly break Fast64 presets (lighting pipeline, combiner assumptions, render modes)?
What is Kaze’s recommended ‘material list’ and how is it shared with collaborators?
Would a custom Fast64 profile/export preset for RTYI reduce friction for artists?
How much time has tool mismatch cost the project overall?

open_questions.topic: Collision remakes as a production bottleneck
open_questions.context: Kaze repeatedly notes he must remake entire collision maps after major geo updates; this is flagged as “the biggest thing” remaining for the Zoo course to be done again.
questions: What is the current collision authoring workflow (Fast64 export, custom scripts, manual fixes)?
How do collisions interact with new moves (ledge grab, dive chaining, etc.)?
What are common failure modes (camera clipping, ledge-grab exploits, sequence breaks like Unagi skip)?

open_questions.context: Kaze argues against frustration-minimized design and explicitly wants players to sometimes struggle or get briefly stuck; he debates minigame timer changes and control precision adjustments.
questions: What are Kaze’s concrete rules for ‘acceptable frustration’ vs unfairness?
How does he test difficulty for different player skill levels?
Where did this philosophy come from (specific childhood games, romhacking culture, speedrunning)?
How does the team resolve disagreements when feedback asks for accessibility/smoothing?

open_questions.context: The Zoo course has distinct sub-areas (Aquarium, Prison, Wario office, Antarctic/plane minigame/landing strip, treasure room) with comedic signage and Wario-as-cheapskate theming.
questions: What is the intended narrative arc of the Zoo course (why these sub-areas, what progression fantasy)?
How did Wario become central to this course’s identity (and why ‘Wario’s Wildlife World’)?
Which jokes/signs are essential vs optional, and how are they localized/validated?

open_questions.topic: Open source strategy and risk management
